My mindset has definitely changed quite a lot since the start of the semester. I knew how capable AI was in industries such as financial management, but I didn't have the knowledge how to contextualize AI tools and use them to my advantage. However, after learning the DRIVER framework and other AI/financial principles, I've learned how to set up AI prompts and give it the information in a way that it can most accurately complete the given task. I know how to prompt it efficiently and work around issues that I would not know how to tackle otherwise. For example, having the opportunity to use AI to automate monthly loan payments and the split between principal/interest is something I really enjoyed. I am pursuing a Real Estate minor at Purdue, so seeing how I can use AI to further my understanding of RE principles with AI was an invaluable experience for me. I also really enjoyed using AI for stock and bond analysis. I actively trade and invest without AI to help me. Now, however, I can utilize AI to help me make better investment decisions and grow my portfolio effectively.

This semester, learning financial management through AI tools has completely reshaped how I view both finance and technology. Initially, I saw AI as something distant, mainly useful for automating tasks. Still, through hands-on use of the OpenAI API, Gemini, n8n, and Python, I realized that AI can be an interactive learning partner that deepens understanding rather than replacing it.
For example, while building an AI-driven finance tool in n8n, I used the OpenAI API to summarize spending patterns and classify transactions into "needs automatically," "wants," and "savings." This process forced me to think critically about prompt design, data accuracy, and ethical use of financial information. Similarly, using Python for portfolio optimization and risk analysis helped me connect financial theories, like expected return and variance, to real data through coding and visualization.
Working with Gemini also showed me the value of cross-checking AI outputs. Comparing its responses with OpenAI's taught me that AI models have strengths and biases, and effective use requires human oversight and financial reasoning.Overall, my mindset about AI has shifted from skepticism to partnership. I've learned that when used responsibly, AI can transform learning by automating routine calculations, visualizing complex relationships, and providing personalized feedback, allowing me to focus on deeper strategic and ethical thinking in financial decision-making.

This semester, I learned how to use AI tools to help me understand financial management. At first, I thought AI was just something to give quick answers. But as I used it more, I saw that it could actually help me learn and think better. For example, when I worked on money problems like budgeting or investments, AI helped me test different ideas and see how changes affected the results. I also used it in group projects to compare financial plans. I learned that AI works best when I ask good questions and still use my own judgment. Now I see AI as a helpful learning partner, not just a shortcut to answers.

This class emphasizes both the importance of utilizing AI with a designated framework and its endless possibilities. Although I have always been optimistic towards AI, I'm being able to use this technology to learn more efficiently and hence become more organized overall with my schoolwork, while retaining the information learned. A specific example that exemplifies  effectively using AI as a learning partner was when I had to produce mini-project 1. I had to create a compound interest visualizer and through the DRIVER framework and looping, I was able to implement a more complex project introducing regular contributions and accounting for inflation. Essentially, evolving it, one step at a time, into a sophisticated tool that models real-world financial planning. Now I am able to explain concepts from that project with ease.

I think my mindset on AI has stayed the same for this course and I think it semi hinders our ability to understand the content. However, there are times when it is beneficial in being able to show us examples and other more developed logics that relates to the content.

I think I am putting a lot of effort to follow the directions and take a long time analyzing the homework but sometimes it seems as there is things that are not being asked that are expected to be in our answers. I think I have found the correct way to fulfill these tasks being asked of me after numerous questions and communicaitons though. I just hope the same expectations that I have been fulfilling continue to be the standard that is being asked. As for that I feel like we are learning many useful tools and different ways to utilize them. I hope to continue to find the best way to work all the apps and tools that you through at me.

Learning financial management with AI tools is really helping me understand how AI can be helpful for the modern world. The DRIVER method has also helped me to better approach my problems and tasks, and I will surely use the DRIVER method in the future for my projects and assignments because I feel it is a very useful technique.

This course has enabled me to utilize AI in finances in a way that I didn't think I could. I knew how to use AI for simple tasks but this course has helped me refine my AI prompting skills in order to obtain deeper, and more insightful responses from AI models. I have learned that in order for an AI model to get useful and exact responses, you must be very specific and clear about your instructions and that it is only as useful as you know how to use it.

I think it has been great overall. I absolutely love that there is enough flexibility with the coursework and also the fact I get to actively integrate AI into this helps with the guilt of using it( happens with other courses.)

My mindset about AI has stayed mostly the same throughout this semester. I have always seen it as a tool that can help improve my work, but I did not realize how powerful it truly is. One of my biggest surprises came from using Base44 to create my Mini Project 1 financial tool, which showed me how capable AI is in developing practical applications. I have learned that AI works best when I use it as a partner, giving my own instructions and applying my own judgment to the results. This class has shown me that AI can greatly enhance how I learn and create when used thoughtfully.

I have learned how to utilize the AI in new ways that I would have never thought of before especially bringing it into the financial workspace. AI is able to create graphics and explain how to do the problem while also  showing the entire process. It more easily allows us to present accurate and clear information in a effective way.

My mindset about AI has changed a little bit since the start of this class. I do have a better understanding of how to use chat gpt or google Gemini to aid my thinking instead of just prompting it for answers. I also have learned that it is not wise to rely on AI for correct answers all the time because it is a tool not an answer machine. Using DRIVE has helped me guide AI to help me solve tough problems. But I still think that this class was a little misguiding for is actually necessary information for us.

My Mindset on using AI has definitely changed as now I am more comfortable prompting my AI and using it as a tool. Even for other classes, it has become a helpful resource for me to learn with and I appreciate the way it helps me understand different topics. AI is definitely an effective learning partner, it can help me with practice problems and I have been using it to prompt me with different scenarios that I can use to practice with. For example, in the last session assignment I did not understand the numbers because it was confusing so I was able to prompt my AI with that issue and it provided me different graphics and charts that helped me see the data visually, ultimately helping me understnad it better.

My mindset about AI has changed slightly. I used to think that AI could only be used as a chatbot. However, that has evolved into understanding that AI can be used for so much more and can even automate tasks. I have also learned how to use it as a learning partner by using it to explain complex concepts and helping me do calculations. I have learned that AI is a very good tool for learning. By prompting it correctly, it can help you learn new things you never thought you could know. A specific example is every session assignment. BY me prompting it right telling it exactly what I want it to do, has allowed me to get the prompts completely correct.

At the start, I was getting good scores on my sessions, but then I got too comfortable with the AI output and had to adjust how I completed the assignments. My learning partner has taught me how to use the loop method on AI output and how to ensure the code is correct, for example, on the last session  he helped me learn how to check and confirm the expected return formula.

I have really enjoyd my experience learning financial management with AI tools this semester. My mindset has continued to grow with every assignment and project that I do; the things I have learned that AI can do in terms of financial management are truly remarkable. It will teach you any concept that you dont know in a completely custom way and in the matter of seconds. Ive also learned that AI can be wrong sometimes computing the numbers, however it is good for structuring financial models or builiding tools like those we make in the mini projects.

Learning with AI tools sometimes can make the learning process more complicated. I think this because for 2 reasons. 1) It is great to get better explanations and much longer debriefs for when to use this formula or what exactly it computes. 2) If AI can be unreliable when it comes to math then why are we only putting equations through it that could potentially be wrong. I am sometimes confused as to why we are being reliant on AI when we are told to think for ourselves. However, I have learned many ways to use AI to my advantage. I now know the proper way to get a good answer from it.

Throughout the semester I have grown significantly in my AI knowledge and usage. Throughout the course I have been able to use AI for things I never thought I would be able to personally do. The first thing that comes to mind is project 2 that I just finished up. I never would have believed that I would come out of a finance class understanding how to create tools that code and do simple for calculations for me. I always believed that to be way to complicated for me to do personally. However, with AI I am able to produce something of substance that helps.

I'd like to think this class has taught me how to use AI more effectively and efficiently, through the DRIVER way of thinking.


 For example, using AI for programming financial calculators throughout this class (something that I could not do without AI and/or tens, if not hundreds, of hours of programming knowledge).

 Another example is comparing prompts and their vastly different (or not) outcomes between learning partners in class, which really helps master the ability to write a well-written prompt that the AI can understand and delve deeper into.
The use of AI can also make learning tedious things more enjoyable

I do think AI makes a lot more errors than I originally thought before this class. I struggled a lot with Mini Project 2 because of how inconsistent it was with AI outputs. I learned how to use AI effectively by just simply asking it questions and when it doesn't provide the output that I had hoped for, I just tweak the prompt until it does. One example is, again, the Mini Project 2. During this project, I could not figure out what to paste into n8n to get the responses to finally say todays date. After a lot of changed prompts and about 100 trial and errors, I was finally able to figure it out.
The thing that changed my mind most about AI was the mini project 2 that I completed this week. It really opened my eyes to how easy it can be to make something so useful with AI.

I feel much more confident in using AI. At school, we were taught to be "ashamed" of AI. Now, we are taught to use it properly. For example, for the Mini-Project 2, I used ChatGPT to give me the prompt to tell my ChatBot instead of me writing it. Even though I could write my own prompt, it is way simpler to do that and it allows me to focus in other tasks that can not be automated and actually need a human touch.

AI has been significantly helpful with this course, it has been a helpful tool to navigate through assignments and questions. It is a great guidance and also a great idea generator. I like how AI is incorporated within this class. However, AI is not 100% the correct answer it still need human to guide and fix the mistakes. It can also be exhausting when training an AI but it is much better to work through homework with AI rather than without.

I think AI really helped me self learn a lot of the This semester, I learned a lot using AI as part of my Financial Management course. I had so many questions throughout the class, and AI really helped me figure things out and improve my weekly assignments. At first, I used AI mostly to get quick answers, but over time, I started to see it more as a tool that actually teaches me.


For example, in Mini Project 2, I was super confused about how to connect my code to the agent. I asked AI how to do it, and it gave me ideas and step-by-step instructions. That helped me understand how n8n works instead of just copying the solution. After that, I felt like I really understood what I was doing and could use the website better.
Overall, my mindset about AI has definitely changed. Now, I use it to guide my learning instead of just getting answers. It's helped me become more confident, and I feel like I can learn new things faster when I use AI the right way.

Being in this class has helped me understand just how powerful of a tool AI really is and can be. I never really used AI before this class. I didn't really know that it was capable of doing so much. To use AI effectively as a tool and aiding in learning, I have learned that your prompts have to be very specific to get what you want out of it. You really have to narrow down what you want out of it because it is capable of so much. I find that it is helpful to tell AI to act as a tutor and that I want to solve a problem using DRIVER. Some of the assignments like the real estate one can have so many moving parts to making a decision and so it was especially important to explain your workflow process. All in all, I have enjoyed getting to learn more about using AI and how to use it to my advantage.

My mindset has shifted a bit, it's become easier for me to navigate AI, though I'm still not very tech-savvy. Because of that, creating an app feels difficult, and I don't fully see the purpose behind it. I understand that it's meant to be a helpful tool, but I'm not sure it's something we really need to do. AI tools like Gemini, however, have been extremely useful for discussions, brainstorming ideas, and exploring different directions. They've helped me analyze the DRIVER method the most, and Gemini has been valuable in every session. In particular, it helped me develop my scenarios in sessions 3, 4, 5, and 6 by guiding how I should allocate and divide my money. For example, in session 6, I compared several ratios between Tesla stock and various bonds to build a portfolio stronger than the S&P 500. It was also helpful in session 3 when deciding how to invest my $75,000 across stocks, bonds, and savings. Gemini's explanations helped me understand the reasoning behind those ratios and made the numbers and percentages in my calculations much clearer.

I am struggling to really be able to learn with AI, I feel like it is a great way to learn more and be able to accomplish things that have never been thought of, but I am struggling to find out how to do that. I am more interested in how prompts affect outputs more though and I am eager to learn how to utilize this tool. I want to be able to know how the calculations work and I am trying to figure it out with my AI learning partner. This is a huge learning curve that I am ready to tackle head on. For example, I want to be able to understand the code and the calculations of what Gemini makes for co lab. I hope to learn how to use AI better than I have been prior, I just need a little help.

Overall throughout this course I feel like I have learned and grown a lot by working with Ai. Before this course I would just use Ai to give me answers to homework or things I was too lazy to do. But now I am actually using Ai to help enhance my learning and my knowledge. I have been getting a lot better with prompting Ai throughout this course to grow my capabilities. For example on our assignments I have to use python code, so I have been getting a lot better with prompting the Ai to output me a python code that is very effective and enhances my work for my assignment. I am really curious to keep learning about Ai because it can do some very powerful things, and I want to be very useful with Ai so that I can be effective in the workforce.

My mindset about AI has almost stayed the same. I say this because I have learned that it can be a fantastic learning and calculation tool for rapid results, but the interpretation and analysis MUST be done by myself. This here is what I've learned about AI over this semester in this course. By leveraging the data provided rapidly from AI, we are able to provide financial results and "advice" to our "clients". I mean this in a sense of real-world applications because AI can be a friend, but it can also be an enemy if you do not know the data it is providing. 


For finance, AI can provide data that needs to be interpreted based on different applications and models (real estate, bonds, CD's, etc.) and this is where I have learned to appreciate this class. Even if we don't grow as financiers, we should be able to determine the best course of action for a potential investment in the future.
Thank you Professor Z

I'd say my mindset on AI has changed in a way in a way that it's been opened to how many possibilities it actually contains. Attempting to use n8n cloud was a interesting experience to say the least but was really fun as I got to connect it to things like Slack and see how AI can be used ourselves rather than plainly depending on Gemini. Moreover, being able to combine what I know and AI's capabilities has been really interesting as I've been able to create things like code which I never would've been able to do before. Previously, I was very AI and AI tool averse in the past, but I've definitely grown to see its capabilities but also, its downfalls and how dependency on it and trusting it blindly can lead to dangerous outcomes. 9 Times out of 10 it's perfect but the remaining time, it will lie to me or tell me something wrong or read something incorrectly such as working with data when I was feeding it information during a session assignment and it is misreading and putting the wrong number down. Overall, my opinion of Ai has grown, and I feel my understanding of it has done just the same.

This class has greatly helped me learn to use AI in a productive way. I did not fully understand the capabilities of AI tools such as gemini in the past, however this class has shown me their usefulness, especially in the finance world. My mindset has become far more optimistic as I have seen how humans can use AI to benefit them instead of replace them. The most important skill I have learned in this class has been learning how to construct prompts to be able to write code efficiently.

My mindset about AI has completely changed over the course of this semester. Earlier I used to see AI as the future that would completely take over the job market, now I see it as a tool and it is not a crutch that should completely over take human think rather it is a tool that can help humans if used and maximized correctly. Using AI effectively is going to be a key tool in the future as every field of study is going to implement it some way or another and it should be used as a learning partner since we should not be completely be dependent on it. During the course of this class I have used AI as a learning partner by only making the AI doing majority of the coding while I would make sense of what it has coded and how it can be used to solve the problem at hand.

My perspective on AI has changed since taking this class. My current understanding of AI is that it is used as a tool to help guide and learn. Using the DRIVER framework that we have been practicing each week really helps line up the different concepts of finance we are learning. I can successfully use AI as a learning partner by giving detailed prompts to AI to learn what I need to learn for the concepts in finance.

I Really like the AI integration in the class. I think we live in a world of AI and AI is the future. Learning how to properly use AI while doing the financial analysis helps me build myself and get ready for the future.

This semester, using AI tools like Gemini for financial management has actually changed the way I learn. At first, I thought AI was just something to get quick answers from, but I started realizing it can really help you understand the "why" behind the numbers. For example, when I was working on things like the CAPM and dividend discount model, Gemini helped me break down what each part of the formula meant instead of just solving it. That made it easier for me to connect everything we learned in class to real situations.


I also used it when I got stuck on topics like portfolio risk and return. It helped me understand how risk affects returns and how to think through my decisions rather than just memorizing terms. Over time, I learned that AI works best when you actually interact with it—ask follow-up questions, double-check what it says, and use it to support your own reasoning.
Overall, this experience made me more open to using AI as a learning tool. It's not a replacement for learning the material myself, but it's been a great way to get feedback, understand concepts faster, and practice applying them to real examples.

I think my mindset have really changed about AI. I think I especially loved learning about the AI agent because I never thought I could create something like that, it really made me feel empowered. I think I have been able to learn so much so quickly but using AI as a learning partner and have deep understanding of finance concepts such as present value and future value.

This semester changed how I think about AI in finance. I used to see AI as a way to cheat with quick answers, but building my loan affordability workflow showed me AI can actually help me learn concepts too. When I gave more specific prompts, like asking how the monthly payment was calculated or what a debt-to-income ratio means, AI explained it clearly after a few attempts and helped me learn the actual reasoning behind the numbers. Now I see AI as a useful learning partner, not something that replaces the work, but something that makes financial decisions easier to understand.
Classes are going better than before, content is clarified and understandable. Still enjoy peer learning and completing our video assignments.

I believe that the DRIVER framework has been a very useful way to approach problems and learn about finances, especially with assistance from AI like Google Gemini. I have come to learn that when you give it the right prompt, AI is very useful and can be a great tool to help become more familiar with terminology as well as figure out how to solve problems inside and outside of school. I still believe many people don't know how to effectively use AI to learn and instead use it to cheat or get shortcuts for assignments, but this class has definitely taught me how to use AI better than I previously have. However, I still don't feel like using AI to learn the concepts in the way that we have has allowed me to learn and feel knowledgeable about these new concepts as I would in the more orthodox way and I feel like I would've learned the concepts better when taking notes from a normal lecture, but I definitely feel like I've benefitted from the assignments in the terms of AI usage and confidence using sites like Replit and n8n to build things. An example of learning through AI usage that I've experienced in this class was learning how to create a better prompt. I think the emails from the professor about things we can improve upon from each assignment has definitely helped me to develop skills with searching things in Gemini and finding effective answers, so that is my biggest takeaway from the class and my learning. I do feel like the instructions for assignments and in class demos could be clearer in the way that they are described, as I feel like when doing assignments, the instruction from the professor can be a bit vague. Also, I think grading can be unfair at times since some people put a lot of work into these assignments just to get an insufficient grade, so it can seem a little unfair at times. But I feel like this class has been more beneficial to me than not so that is good. I look forward to seeing how the rest of the semester goes.

Honestly, it has only strengthened my opinion on AI. It is key to be the one driving AI, not to become entirely dependent on it. You must be able to differentiate your strengths from those of AI, as if your key strengths are replaceable by AI, you will become obsolete. Using AI to drive my financial analysis has been extremely helpful so far, and I have been able to produce key data to inform my decisions on investments, loan calculations, and related matters. Being able to use AI to help commandeer my Python code has also been extremely helpful in coding functions and complex compounding equations. My favorite example was our session assignment in which we were given a hypothetical portfolio and return rates, and found the optimal split between more aggressive stocks (Tesla) and more conservative ones (S&P) and bonds.

I feel like my mindset about AI has evolved a lot. I feel that I was barely reaching its potential. Because I used it for questions or help studying, but in this class I've learned that it can do so much more, and I've appreaciate to have learned what more it can do. I also learned that it is highly effective as a learining, it responds any doubt I ever have and explains to me the problems I may have trying to understand something. My examples would be the mini-projects like creating an AI and the python codes he can formulate by just naming a problem.

My experience in learning financial management with AI tools this semester has been nothing short of great. My mindset on AI has changed drastically because i now see it as a tool for finance not a tool to find answers. I have learned that i can use AI to help me code and make strategic financial decisions about stocks and bonds and how to diversify my portfolios for risk management. In this course, I am most excited for the stocks and portfolio management. Like right now, we are learning how to mitigate risks by diversifying portfolios and how to create good purchases.

So far, my experience with learning financial management using AI has been challenging yet useful. So far, learning financial management with the integration of AI has been both challenging and rewarding. The first mini-project was particularly difficult due to some technical issues, but the second project was engaging and introduced me to entirely new concepts and tools. Despite the challenges, I've gained more practical knowledge than I would have in a traditional financial management class without the AI component.


My mindset in the beginning was open-minded but nervous for the new learning curves to come, and that has been consistent so far, but I am feeling more confident in using some of these applications now that I never knew existed.
AI is a useful tool, but it is just that- a tool. It can only be as good as the person using it. That is why it is important to do what we are doing each day: learning how to DRIVE(R) AI so that it delivers results that we want and accurate results.

Personally, I have not found the AI to be much help in my learning of the course; in fact, I feel that it has hindered it. Obviously, AI is important and will impact all of our lives moving forward, but this takes away from actually learning the material. Luckily, I am an actuarial science major, so I come into the course with lots of prior knowledge on the subject, but my class partner, who doesn't have that background, is struggling. AI has replaced the learning, and no other MGMT 310 course focuses this heavily on AI. I haven't found the assignments to be particularly helpful for improving my knowledge. The whole point of the course is to get a background on finance, but because everyone uses AI, there is no point in learning the material. I feel the assignments should be structured differently to not include as much reliance on AI. I understand AI is not supposed to replace learning, but unfortunately, that's what a lot of people do, so instead of encouraging that, changes should be made to teach the material without such a heavy reliance on AI.

I understand that we are trying to learn how to use AI with these financial concepts but lately I've been feeling that I don't fully understand the financial concepts or that I thought I understood things but maybe I didn't and I've been using AI as a crutch. I think this class is trying to do a good thing by involving AI but in my opinion we should also be practicing how to use the equations we've learned by hand because doing it by hand and without the aid of any technology ensures you fully understand the financial concepts. Then once you have proven you understand these financial concepts and equations by hand, AI should be integrated into the work.

Coming into this semester, I did not expect to be using AI as a tool to learn financial management. However, even though I didn't expect it, I will say it has been a tool that's helped me learn financial management in new ways. For example, in the assignment "Mini Project 1", we were prompted to create an app that helped us solve real world financial scenarios such as calculating Earned Interest over time or Bond Investing tips. 

By using AI as a learning partner, I have to admit that it has improved my knowledge of financial management and certain real-life scenarios. Overall, AI can be used a versatile learning tool that helps students apply what's demonstrated throughout in class assignments, to real world scenarios.

By applying AI, I have transformed my approach to learning, making it more dynamic and efficient. For instance, I recently developed a practical tool to analyze bond investments (Session 4) and conducted a data-driven analysis of APR to model the financial implications of renting versus buying (Session 5). These applications sharpened my ability to turn complex data into actionable financial insights.

My mindset toward AI in finance has completely changed this semester. I started hesitant, but now I'm fully open and feel knowledgeable about how to use AI as an effective learning partner. The key was learning to guide the AI, especially using the DRIVER framework, which taught me how to move beyond simple questions. This new approach allowed me to gain valuable, real-world insights in complex areas. For example:


I was able to deeply analyze stock versus bond decisions, modeling different scenarios instead of just getting a basic definition.

I used the AI to explore the rent versus buy dilemma with specific variables, helping me understand the long-term implications.
By learning to direct the AI, I've been able to use it as a true collaborator and feel much more prepared to make financial decisions in the future.

For a while, and even at the beginning of this semester, I have viewed AI as a tool for getting answers fast. However, this class has taught me that AI is more than just that; it is also a great helper in guiding a thinking process. 

For example, working through problems such as break-even analysis, I used AI to walk me through the formulas, that way I gained a better understanding of the purpose of certain tools and gain a deeper understanding of how to solve for problems. On the contrary, I have found that this class is a little difficult for me to relate to the real world at times. For example, I tend to struggle on the interactive assignments, but using these tools has helped me to bridge that gap a little bit.

I have always been hesitant to use AI as I thought it would take away from me using my skills to my fullest ability; however, after using AI in this class, my mindset has changed. I now see how AI is essentially only a tool to be used to make tasks more efficient. I have learnt how to leverage it to bring my unique ideas and skills into my work. After using AI as a learning partner for a while, I have learned how important a prompt can be, as it can be the difference maker in concrete and solid responses from the AI. An example of this would include the gradual improvement in my prompt writing for the homework assignments, as I realised that by not being clear and including more detail in the prompt it now only gives the AI less information to work with, but also doesn't allow me to test my understanding of the content.

I have enjoyed learning how to use AI more. When used correctly I understand how it can be a tool instead of something that is putting my learning to a halt. It helps the concepts make a lot more sense because it fully explains them and is able to represent them. When I think about using AI now I feel confident that I can use it as a learning tool instead of a supplement to doing my homework assignments. I've learned how important it is to keep it simple. When you overcomplicate things or ask AI too much any once many parts could be missed that are very basic and not overly complicated.  For example, when doing my session assignments sometimes if I ask chat too much at one time, it will not properly complete the assignment. I will have to reiterate certain points of the assignment that are important.

Throughout the course, I think I use a lot of Google Gemini AI to the coding(like Python), and it helps a lot with all the calculations. Before the class I already feel like AI is the great help for life in general, but as now I learned that AI can also do your coding like this, it just expend my horizon, and very much suprisied me.

I realized how important it has become to understand how to use AI since all companies are implenting it in some ways. I realized this when we were looking at the Accenture article in class. I learned that it is good at providing analysis but it's calculations are not very accurate. Therefore, whenever I have to make any calculations I ask it to generate python code because that consistently provides correct answers.

My mindset has stayed the same about using AI effectively as a learning partner. It is important to use it as a tool and helper, and not a replacement. It is also important to always validate and check and do the calculations on your own before implementing AI. I also have learned the importance of correct prompts and how being specific is extremely important when making sure that accurate data is given. For example, when using AI to help with Time Value of Money Calculations and Risk Portfolio decisions, it is extremely important to provide the exact, textbook formulas and analysis that you want AI to help with. This is to help with more relevant answers and not as broad, not specified answers that don't do much for an analysis.

This semester, using AI tools in financial management demonstrated to me that AI can help break down complex topics, such as formulas and spreadsheets, into simple steps. My mindset has changed because I used to think AI just provided answers, but now I see that it works best when I guide it with clear instructions and double-check the results myself. Overall, I learned that AI is a helpful learning partner, not a shortcut, because it supports my understanding instead of replacing it.

As we reach the halfway point in this class, I can honestly say it has been really beneficial in teaching me how to use AI more smartly. When I started, I didn't know much about coding or how AI tools actually worked behind the scenes. I thought AI was just something that gave quick answers. Reflection: My Semester Learning Finance with an AI Partner
This semester, integrating AI tools into my financial management studies wasn't just helpful—it fundamentally changed my approach to learning. Initially, I was skeptical, but my experience has been overwhelmingly positive, shifting my mindset and equipping me with new, effective learning strategies.
My Evolving Mindset: From "Magic 8-Ball" to "Co-Pilot"
At the start of the semester, I viewed AI (like ChatGPT or Gemini) as a "magic 8-ball"—a tool for getting quick, simple answers. I'd ask it "What is the formula for the Sharpe Ratio?" and just copy the answer. I was wary of its accuracy for complex topics and saw it as a shortcut, not a genuine learning partner.
My mindset has completely changed. I now see AI as a collaborative learning partner, or a "co-pilot." The crucial shift happened when I realized AI's strength isn't just giving answers, but helping me explore them. It's a patient, 24/7 tutor that I can ask to re-explain a concept in five different ways without it getting frustrated. It's a sounding board for my own ideas, helping me refine my understanding before I ever get to class.

What I Learned: Using AI Effectively

This mindset shift was driven by learning how to use the tool effectively. Here are the key strategies I developed:

Iterative Questioning: I stopped asking for simple definitions. Instead, I learned to build understanding layer by layer.
Example (Time Value of Money): I didn't just ask, "What is TVM?" I started a conversation:
"Explain the concept of Time Value of Money in simple terms."
"Okay, now show me the formula for Present Value (PV) and explain each component."
"Give me a practical example: If I need $10,000 in 5 years for a down payment and can get a 6% annual return, how much do I need to invest today?"
"What happens to that number if inflation is 3%?" This iterative process turned a abstract formula into a concrete, usable tool.

AI as a Simulator: This was a game-changer for me, especially for risk management.
Example (Portfolio Management): I would ask the AI to "Act as a financial advisor. My portfolio is 60% stocks (S&P 500) and 40% bonds (U.S. Treasurys). What is the likely impact on my portfolio if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates by 0.50%? Explain your reasoning." This "what-if" scenario planning made the theoretical relationship between interest rates and asset prices feel real and tangible.
Concept "Translator": Financial textbooks and articles can be incredibly dense.
Example (WACC): When I was struggling with the Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC), I pasted a dense textbook definition into the AI and prompted it: "Explain this to me like I'm a 10th grader starting a small business." It broke down the jargon (like "cost of equity" and "cost of debt") into simple terms about bank loans and investor expectations, making the entire concept click.
A "Smarter" Study Guide: Instead of just re-reading notes, I used the AI to actively test myself.
Example (Exam Prep): I would prompt it with, "I'm studying for a financial management exam. Ask me 10 questions about capital budgeting, including net present value (NPV) and internal rate of return (IRR). Don't give me the answers until I try first." This active recall was far more effective than passive reading.

In conclusion, this semester taught me two things: financial management, and how to learn with AI. My mindset has shifted from seeing AI as a simple tool for answers to seeing it as a powerful partner for exploration. The key is not what you ask it, but how you ask—by being specific, iterative, and creative, I've unlocked a new way of learning that I know I'll use long after this course is over.

This semester changed how I think about AI in finance. At the beginning, I mostly saw AI as a fast calculator: give it numbers, get an answer. But in this class I started using it more like a partner that helps me think. I would ask AI to help me set up the problem using DRIVER: What decision are we making? What are the important inputs? Which assumptions really matter? That helped me move from "here is the IRR" to "should we actually do this project and why?" For example, in the risk and return work, AI helped me talk through base case, upside case, and downside case for two portfolios, and then make a real rule like, "We only invest if it still beats our hurdle in base and downside." That made me understand finance the way someone in FP&A or corporate planning would talk, not just like homework.

I also learned to ask better questions. Instead of asking AI "what's the answer," I started asking, "Which assumption is the most dangerous here?" and "How would I explain this to a CFO?" AI helped me label assumptions with confidence levels (high, medium, low) and think about what happens if things go worse than expected. That made me see that in finance, the point is not just the number — the point is how you defend the number under uncertainty. At the same time, I learned AI is not perfect. If you just copy what it gives you, it might quietly assume timing or cash flow details that aren't true for the case. So now I treat AI like a junior analyst: it can organize, structure, and stress test, but I still have to check the logic. Overall, I trust AI more for thinking, but I also respect that I'm the one responsible for the final call.
